title: [BUG] Kalman Filter implementation returns high variation results
body:
From the discussion forum, looks like a bug. --- ### Discussed in https://github.com/sktime/sktime/discussions/3696
Originally posted by **raul-parada** November 3, 2022 I would like to correct some predictions, I thought to use the Kalman filter to align the values. I've used the following code: ``` import numpy as np import sktime.transformations.series.kalman_filter as kf time_steps, state_dim, measurement_dim = 10, 5, 10 X=pd.concat([pd.DataFrame(df2['a']),pd.DataFrame(df2['b']),pd.DataFrame(df2['c']),pd.DataFrame(df2['d']),pd.DataFrame(df2['e'])],axis=1) transformer = kf.KalmanFilterTransformerPK(state_dim=state_dim) X_transformed = transformer.fit_transform(X=X) ``` The X variable is the following: ``` a b c d e 50 41.392399 2.163121 11.389426 45.086289 -17.450777 51 41.392647 2.163214 11.404417 45.086109 -20.773808 52 41.392892 2.163307 11.363195 45.085834 -2.760342 53 41.392856 2.163401 11.347862 45.085834 -4.309544 54 41.393087 2.163494 11.369231 45.086680 -5.170121 55 41.393178 2.163587 11.370940 45.086697 -5.744848 56 41.393216 2.163681 11.366240 45.086698 -6.428164 57 41.393275 2.163774 11.364492 45.086699 -7.315250 58 41.393374 2.163868 11.366929 45.086699 -8.091960 59 41.393452 2.163961 11.367124 45.086694 -8.827055 ``` And the transformed one, the following: ``` a b c d e 50 20.696199 1.081560 5.694713 22.543144 -8.725388 51 33.114068 1.730553 9.120535 36.068923 -15.954440 52 38.208729 1.996863 10.500633 41.617792 -7.834995 53 40.175395 2.099725 11.023922 43.759818 -5.657510 54 40.927901 2.139133 11.237315 44.579789 -5.356315 55 41.215455 2.154246 11.319899 44.893071 -5.596438 56 41.325317 2.160077 11.348540 45.012739 -6.110472 57 41.367317 2.162362 11.358399 45.058449 -6.855066 58 41.383421 2.163293 11.363671 45.075908 -7.619508 59 41.389621 2.163706 11.365805 45.082575 -8.365813 ``` As observed, the values differ too much from the first row (50) wrt the last one (59) at least in the columns a and b. I was thinking to append at the beginning the original training samples, however, I want to correct only the last ten values. Is it possible to compute it with sktime? How can I get logical values? Thank you for your time.
